        public HIStyle style
        Shared CSS styles for all labels.

        default:

         { "color": "#333333" }

      • y

        public java.lang.Number y
        description: The y position offset of the label relative to the tick position on the axis. demo:  •  https://jsfiddle.net/gh/get/library/pure/highcharts/highcharts/tree/master/samples/highcharts/xaxis/labels-x/ : Y axis labels placed on grid lines* default: 3

      • x

        public java.lang.Number x
        description: The x position offset of the label relative to the tick position on the axis. Defaults to -15 for left axis, 15 for right axis. demo:  •  https://jsfiddle.net/gh/get/library/pure/highcharts/highcharts/tree/master/samples/highcharts/xaxis/labels-x/ : Y axis labels placed on grid lines

      • align

        public java.lang.String align
        description: What part of the string the given position is anchored to. Can be one of "left", "center" or "right". The exact position also depends on the labels.x setting. Angular gauges and solid gauges defaults to center. demo:  •  https://jsfiddle.net/gh/get/library/pure/highcharts/highcharts/tree/master/samples/highcharts/yaxis/labels-align-left/ : Left* accepted values: ["left", "center", "right"] default: right

      • distance

        public java.lang.Number distance
        description: Angular gauges and solid gauges only. The label's pixel distance from the perimeter of the plot area. default: -25

      • zIndex

        public java.lang.Number zIndex
        The Z index for the axis labels.

        default:

         7

      • reserveSpace

        public java.lang.Boolean reserveSpace
        Whether to reserve space for the labels. By default, space is reserved for the labels in these cases: On all horizontal axes. On vertical axes if label.align is right on a left-side axis or left on a right-side axis. On vertical axes if label.align is center. This can be turned off when for example the labels are rendered inside the plot area instead of outside.

        Try it:

         •  No reserved space, labels inside plot
         •  Left-aligned labels on a vertical category axis

        default:

         null

      • format

        public java.lang.String format
        A [format string](http://www.highcharts.com/docs/chart- concepts/labels-and-string-formatting) for the axis label.

        Try it:

         •  Add units to Y axis label

        default:

         {value}

      • autoRotationLimit

        public java.lang.Number autoRotationLimit
        When each category width is more than this many pixels, we don't apply auto rotation. Instead, we lay out the axis label with word wrap. A lower limit makes sense when the label contains multiple short words that don't extend the available horizontal space for each label.

        Try it:

         •  Lower limit

        default:

         80

      • enabled

        public java.lang.Boolean enabled
        Enable or disable the axis labels.

        Try it:

         •  X axis labels disabled

        default:

         true

      • staggerLines

        public java.lang.Number staggerLines
        Horizontal axes only. The number of lines to spread the labels over to make room or tighter labels.

        Try it:

         •  Show labels over two lines

        default:

         null

      • position3d

        public java.lang.String position3d
        Defines how the labels are be repositioned according to the 3D chart orientation. - 'offset': Maintain a fixed horizontal/vertical distance from the tick marks, despite the chart orientation. This is the backwards compatible behavior, and causes skewing of X and Z axes. - 'chart': Preserve 3D position relative to the chart. This looks nice, but hard to read if the text isn't forward-facing. - 'flap': Rotated text along the axis to compensate for the chart orientation. This tries to maintain text as legible as possible on all orientations. - 'ortho': Rotated text along the axis direction so that the labels are orthogonal to the axis. This is very similar to 'flap', but prevents skewing the labels (X and Y scaling are still present).

        Try it:

         •  Skewed labels

        accepted values:

         ['offset', 'chart', 'flap', 'ortho']

      • useHTML

        public java.lang.Boolean useHTML
        Whether to [use HTML](http://www.highcharts.com/docs/chart- concepts/labels-and-string-formatting#html) to render the labels.

        default:

         false

      • padding

        public java.lang.Number padding
        The pixel padding for axis labels, to ensure white space between them.

        default:

         5

      • step

        public java.lang.Number step
        To show only every _n_'th label on the axis, set the step to _n_. Setting the step to 2 shows every other label. By default, the step is calculated automatically to avoid overlap. To prevent this, set it to 1\. This usually only happens on a category axis, and is often a sign that you have chosen the wrong axis type. Read more at [Axis docs](http://www.highcharts.com/docs/chart-concepts/axes) => What axis should I use?

        Try it:

         •  Showing only every other axis label on a categorized x axis
         •  Auto steps on a category axis

        default:

         null

      • skew3d

        public java.lang.Boolean skew3d
        If enabled, the axis labels will skewed to follow the perspective. This will fix overlapping labels and titles, but texts become less legible due to the distortion. The final appearance depends heavily on labels.position3d.

        Try it:

         •  Skewed labels

      • formatter

        public HIFunction formatter
        Callback JavaScript function to format the label. The value is given by this.value. Additional properties for this are axis, chart, isFirst and isLast. The value of the default label formatter can be retrieved by calling this.axis.defaultLabelFormatter.call(this) within the function. Defaults to: function() { return this.value; }

        Try it:

         •  Linked category names
         •  Modified numeric labels

      • rotation

        public java.lang.Number rotation
        Rotation of the labels in degrees.

        Try it:

         •  X axis labels rotated 90ĂÂ°

        default:

         0

      • autoRotation

        public java.util.ArrayList<java.lang.Number> autoRotation
        For horizontal axes, the allowed degrees of label rotation to prevent overlapping labels. If there is enough space, labels are not rotated. As the chart gets narrower, it will start rotating the labels -45 degrees, then remove every second label and try again with rotations 0 and -45 etc. Set it to false to disable rotation, which will cause the labels to word-wrap if possible.

        Try it:

         •  Default auto rotation of 0 or -45
         •  Custom graded auto rotation

        default:

         [-45]

      • point

        public HIPoint point
        This option defines the point to which the label will be connected. It can be either the point which exists in the series - it is referenced by the point's id - or a new point with defined x, y properies and optionally axes.

        Try it:

         •  Attach annotation to a mock point

      • allowOverlap

        public java.lang.Boolean allowOverlap
        Whether to allow the annotation's labels to overlap. To make the labels less sensitive for overlapping, the can be set to 0.

        Try it:

         •  Hide overlapping labels

      • borderColor

        public HIColor borderColor
        The border color for the annotation's label.

        Try it:

         •  Set labels graphic options

        public java.lang.String verticalAlign
        The vertical alignment of the annotation's label.

        accepted values:

         ["top", "middle", "bottom"]

        Try it:

        The background color or gradient for the annotation's label.

        Try it:

      • overflow

        public java.lang.String overflow
        How to handle the annotation's label that flow outside the plot area. The justify option aligns the label inside the plot area.

        Try it:

         •  Crop or justify labels

        accepted values:

         ["none", "justify"]

      • shadow

        public java.lang.Object shadow
        The shadow of the box. The shadow can be an object configuration containing color, offsetX, offsetY, opacity and width.

        Try it:

         •  Set labels graphic options
